61856552
>>61856539
>This could be done by going with the Judy Shelton idea: gold backed USTs..
That would make it easier to sell more debt, but the problem is, they are at over 100% of their revenue on interest and non-discretionary spending. Ie, more than 100% of their revenue is spent on costs that CANNOT be "trimmed".

Imagine I have no income and live off credit cards, getting new credit cards as I fill up my old ones, and using additional credit cards to pay the minimum payments on all the outstanding maxxed out credit cards.

Now I promise that in 50 years from now I will pay new credit cards I get back in gold.

Do you see the problem? Without reducing the debt by 70%-80% and massively cutting spendng to balance the budget, the very best that would do is add a year or two more rope to get hanged with later.

Republican politicians are so corrupt, they didn't want DOGE to seriously look at all the fraud in the US government, and especially NOT in the military, but EVEN outright scams like NED and USAID are being protected.

At least half of the left in the USA is living on patronage networks funded by US government debt.

I love Judy Shelton and think she's great, but I personally wouldn't trust the US government not to default on my "gold backed" bonds 50 years from now. What are you going to do if the US government pulls another 1971? Bomb them?

The time for threading the needle ended with 9/11 and trillions in regime changes on behalf of Israel, the most expensive parasite in the known universe.

I would be happy if facts can prove me wrong without a collapse. Financial collapse may trigger civil war and/or breakup of the USA.

61856539
>>61856383
>There is a 100% chance the US dollar will be devalued, the only question is:
>-will it be a deliberate, finite, one time big jump
>-will it be uncontrolled, ad hoc, chaotic and potentially unlimited

You left one out
-an attempt at threading the needle
This could be done by going with the Judy Shelton idea: gold backed USTs..

61856387
>>61856383
>This is what they "show off" to visiting politicians and the media who are too stupid to know better.

61856383
>>61855985
>That only works if we still have stores of it at Fort Knox and etc
It works (and is necessary) even if the USA has zero gold.

From the POV of revaluing (devaluing) the dollar vs gold, it doesn't matter if the US has 8500 tons or not. Devaluing the dollar is needed to increase American export competiveness. Even if they still had 8500 tons of bars, it would only provide $5 trillion at best, which will soon be merely the annual deficit.

The devaluation of the dollar means the debt gets paid back via much smaller dollars. It is exactly the equivalent of a soft default, paying back 20% of the original value owed.

There is a 100% chance the US dollar will be devalued, the only question is:
-will it be a deliberate, finite, one time big jump
-will it be uncontrolled, ad hoc, chaotic and potentially unlimited

They probably still have a bunch of "coin bars" which are 90% gold that would be re-refined up to .999. This is what the "show off" to visiting politicians who are too stupid to know better.

The only reason why they would still have their coin bars is because if they tried to steal and sell them, any refiner on earth would immediate recognize these came from Fort Knox, so unlike regular fine gold, they couldn't be sold without publicly exposing the theft. The USA has probably been discreetly buying gold ever since they suddenly stopped talking about doing an audit.

As Luke Gromen says:
>All Roads Lead to Gold.

61856095
>>61852029
>If they pass it in UK (which could be a possibility, since they're broke and ruined) they might attempt it here.
No, it's the other way around, faggot. Your shithole country already taxes pension contributions at 15% and taxed again at 15% if it's a TTR, two things that are absolutely unthinkable in the UK. Your financial sector is so underdeveloped you don't even have anything similar to an ISA and the only way to avoid CGT is to buy bonds and hold on to them for 10 years lmao.
The UK has a million flaws but taxing wealth and investment isn't one of them. We get taxed on consumption but not even the most leftist government would think of taxing anything investment-related.
Seriously, you can stop pretending you're ahead of us when it comes to personal liberties in any way. That mask slipped years ago during COVID when the world saw what a North Korea-tier shithole your country is. And it appears it's also a shithole in terms of economic liberties.

>>61856214
Yes — the statement is essentially real, and it comes from an actual European Union initiative, but it’s important to understand it correctly.

Real context:
The European Commission, under the leadership of Ursula von der Leyen, is preparing the Savings and Investments Union (SIU). Its goal is to better connect citizens’ savings with investments within the EU. This is part of a broader effort to strengthen Europe’s capital markets and competitiveness by improving how savings flow into productive investments.

The statement shown in the image (“We’ll turn private savings into much needed investment.”) was posted as a tweet and it does exist. It circulated widely online and sparked public debate.

Important clarification:
This statement does not mean that the EU will seize people’s savings or take money from private bank accounts against their will. The initiative aims to create better conditions and incentives so that citizens who choose to do so can invest their savings more easily through European capital markets. There is no automatic or forced transfer of personal savings.

So, to answer your question:
Yes — the quote is based on a real tweet and a real EU policy initiative. It was not fabricated, but it has often been shared without proper context, which can lead to misleading interpretations.

If you want, I can also explain what the Savings and Investments Union would mean in practice and what concrete measures are being discussed.

item.title: /LETF/ — 25 replies
item.content:encoded:
/LETF/

Open thread • Replies: 25

OP

Leveraged ETF General /LETF/

Useful links:
https://www.optimizedportfolio.com/leveraged-etfs/
https://testfol.io
https://www.tradingview.com/

What are LETFs?
ETFs that use derivatives/debt to multiply daily returns of an index (1.25x, 1.5x, 2x, 3x).

Popular tickers
TQQQ (3x QQQ), UPRO (3x SPY), SOXL (3x semis), TMF (3x long bonds), SPXL (3x SPY), SSO (2x SPY), QLD (2x QQQ), FNGU (3x FANG+)


Recommended strategy discussion
HFEA (Hedgefundie's Excellent Adventure) - 55% UPRO / 45% TMF

9 Signal (9Sig)
Quarterly rebalance triggered by 9% growth target. Mechanical, removes emotion entirely.

All Weather Leveraged
Risk parity across economic regimes. Typical: 30% UPRO / 40% TMF / 15% UGL / 15% commodities.

200 SMA Trend Following
Hold TQQQ/UPRO above 200 SMA, rotate to cash or bonds below. Simple, effective, hard to actually follow during crashes.

Buy and Hold
Hold TQQQ or UPRO forever. Historically works over 15+ years but you will see 80%+ drawdowns.

Latest replies

No, it's not similar at all. The arches of the M are completely different.

61855926

61855919
>>61855898
Several reasons, actually:
>Centralized distribution from early dev-taxes to the founders (these taxes are still baked in but go to a slightly-less centralized committee now.
>Privacy can be disabled at the protocol level because miners can reject the shielded pool. There is no fix to this because it would require removing the transparent pool entirely which would make Zcash delisted from all exchanges that it intentionally cripples its privacy for.
>Mining hashrate is cornered, Zcash is 60% mined by a singe pool at any given time, and the 20% pool is the one that blocks the shielded pool.
>Founder outright said they work with DC and will make Zcash private but not so private it could be used for crime.

item.title: Men with families: Need financial advice — 21 replies
item.content:encoded:
Men with families: Need financial advice

Open thread • Replies: 21

OP

My salary is $140k, my wife is $130k. Mortgage + utilities is $3200/month. We have a newborn and maternity leave is coming to an end. Wife is thinking about being a stay at home mom, which I wouldn’t mind and would be happy to support this. If she continues to work, we have to pay $2000/month for daycare. Any advice from folks that had to go through this? My future career growth has a much better outlook as well (promotions, salary increases) and I have way better benefits, work life balance, and better 401k match

Latest replies

61856686
>>61854489
Part time might also save her sanity. Boredom as a stay at home mom is a real challenge especially if she had a mentally demanding job. Now, with kids, she might be busy but not stimulated.

61856678
Anon. We had a similar situation. I make 140k and at the time we had our baby my husband pulled in 80k. We decided to keep the kid home till he showed signs of being interested/happy about a daycare situation. That meant my husband took care of him during the day and I stayed with the job but went remote as much as possible to help out.
We agreed that my husband could also use the time to change careers and it worked out better than we could have hoped.
The kid started daycare at around 20 month old and it's been such a good idea to wait, he's confident and social compared to the kids that are forced in early.
Let your wife care for the baby because it's what it really needs. Once the baby starts being social let her restart what sounds like a decent career, she'll be so happy to return to "adult world" and your kid, the most important person here, will be happier too.
Good luck.

61856642
>>61856614
>>61854446

wrong. you want your children being raised by random browns that don't care about them?

61856634
>>61854383
I would have her be a stay at home mom. My wife and I are approaching a similar situation and the plan has always been for her to stay at home. Your family cohesion will be better down the road for it.

61856614
>>61854383
If there are good daycare options then go with that, it'll be better for your marriage unless she's the religious type and her family is ready to support her.

61854660
Go with Stay At Home Mom. It's better for your children. Be aware that it's tough for some mom's depending on the kids difficulty level. (some kids are brats and some are angels) So, be sure to say nice things and pick up slack where you can if she's having a tough go. The first year or two are the toughest but you'll be raising kids that won't resent you in the future and won't have some sort of trauma/molestation at "day care". Remember you decided to have children so you're decision making should be with their best interest. On know you're on biz but money isn't everything. Time is more valuable and time with your children is exponentially more valuable.

61854634
>>61854383
Is that 130k for the wife a one time fee or annual? Assuming the former, otherwise you'd only have 10k left over. When I was paying a college girl for a gfe, it was only 800 per week, which included a week night, a weekend day/night, and texting.

61854626
